abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Hunan Power
            Development Project in the People's Republic of China
            was satisfactory, with a highly likely sustainability,
            substantial institutional development impact, and
            satisfactory performances by both the Bank and Borrower.
            The main objective of the project was to alleviate power
            shortages in Hunan by providing efficient, reliable and
            environmentally sound power supply.  Lessons learned
            include: more practical and realistic cost estimates should
            be used so as to optimize the Borrower's financing
            cost; when the sector is undergoing major changes and the
            borrower's capacity is building up quickly, flexibility
            should be built into the design of the technical assistance
            (TA) component; in the face of changes in circumstances,
            both the Bank and the Borrower should pay closer attention
            to the relevance of the financial covenants, and seek to
            make modifications proactively; when the environmental units
            had the full support of management at the highest level, and
            there was a culture of professionalism and understanding of
            the environmental aspects, it was easy to build upon this
            and implement the Environmental Management Program (EMP);
            strong commitment by the various levels of government and
            the project owner, timely dissemination of information and
            early involvement of media and communities; comprehensive
            resettlement policies supported by consistent and
            transparent principles; adequate planning with regular
            updates based on feedbacks; and effective implementation
            arrangements all contributed to the smooth and successful
            implementation of the Resettlement Action Plan (RAP).

abstracts.cdata!:
The Hunan Power Development Project aims
            to alleviate power shortages by providing an efficient,
            reliable, and environmentally sound power supply. There are
            four components. The Leiyang Power Plant Component supplies
            and installs two additional anthracite-fired generating
            units to alleviate power shortages, improve the generation
            mix, and facilitate the retirement of 10 small, aging,
            inefficient, and polluting generating units in the
            provincial power grid. The second, the Transmission
            Component, reinforces the existing network and constructs
            transmission lines and a number of substations with line
            transfer capability. The third component comprises technical
            assistance for construction management, advisory services to
            help implement the electric power company's (HEPC)
            restructuring plan, and consulting services for HEPC's
            organization restructuring and improvement of its financial
            management system. The fourth component consists of a
            management development and training program designed to
            enhance HEPC's managerial, legal, technical, and
            financial capabilities.

repnme.cdata!:
China - Hunan Power Development Project -
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental assessment of
            Phase 2 of the Hunan Power Development Project, which
            constructs the Leiyang Power Plant--an additional thermal
            power station using anthracite coal, two transmission lines,
            and associated substations. These measures mitigate impacts
            from plant, substation, and transmission line construction
            and operation: Wastewater, drainage, and domestic sewage
            will be treated, used in ash sluicing, and the ash water
            reclaimed later for re-use. The ash lagoon will encroach on
            vegetation, but not result in any significant habitat loss.
            A drainage ditch will redirect and recirculate all ash water
            and ash dam seepage within the power station. Ash
            by-products will either be stored in lagoons, used in
            construction, or dried for fly ash use. Control noise by
            adopting silencers and sound insulation, among other
            measures. Using a boiler with low NOx combustion technology
            will control emissions, and studies will decide whether to
            improve dispersion or further distance the sites from each
            other. Maintain clearance over trees, other power lines,
            roads, railways, etc. Suitable species will be planted to
            replace felled trees and to revegetate. Use water sprays to
            suppress dust emissions. Collect runoff and let it settle to
            discharge suspended solid emissions. Collect domestic sewage
            in septic tanks or sewers. Routing will minimize
            relocations. Compensate crop loss and project-occupied land,
            and quickly reinstate land after use.
